subject: Re: Greetings!
msgSnippet: Hi Ann! How nice that you ve discovered quickscript. I ve been using it for two years now, and I still think it s great. ...  wrote:  ...
messageBody:
Hi Ann!

How nice that you've discovered quickscript. I've been using it for
two years now, and I still think it's great.

--- In Read_Alphabet@yahoogroups.com, "the_coffee_goddess"
<cinnamon70@...> wrote:
<snip>
> I'm only at the point of having skimmed through the manual and am
> wondering how to start. What is the best way to learn QT? Are there
> certain letters and combinations I should start with? Shall I learn it
> the same way my 7-year-old is learning to write and spell (i.e.,
> repetition in writing certain letter combinations).
<snip>

I think the best way to learn it is to grab some English text (maybe a
passage from the bible or something like that) and to transcribe it in
quickscript. If you do that for two or three pages, you'll know the
alphabet thoroughly without much effort. And also try doing it
backwards: transcribing your quickscript sample into Roman. You'll
notice that you don't learn reading and writing simultaneously, but
separately.

You can also practive reading individual letters at my website
http://www.xs4all.nl/~ransau/quickscript/letters_oefenen/ .

I hope that you'll enjoy quickscript.

--
Jerry
